title: Italy Clinches Third Straight Davis Cup Title With 2-0 Win Over Spain
snippets: Italy remains the king of the Davis Cup -- and didn't even need Jannik Sinner this time.
Italy were crowned Davis Cup champions for a third successive year with victory over Spain.

BOLOGNA, Italy — Italy remains the king of the Davis Cup — and didn’t even need Jannik Sinner this time. Matteo Berrettini and Flavio Cobolli were the stars for the Italians without the absent Sinner, both winning their singles matches to earn an unassailable 2-0 lead over Spain in the final on Sunday. It’s a fourth Davis Cup title for Italy, and a third in a row. The last nation to win three straight titles was the United States, which won five on the bounce from 1968-72. The second-ranked Sinner, who led Italy to men’s tennis biggest team trophy the past two years, opted out of playing this...
Flavio Cobolli and Matteo Berrettini lead Italy to a historic third straight Davis Cup title in Bologna.
titles: Italy sweeps Spain, reigns again as Davis champs
Italy beat Spain to complete Davis Cup treble
Italy sweeps Spain to retain Davis Cup
Italy win historic third straight Davis Cup title
summary: Italy won its third consecutive Davis Cup title by defeating Spain in the final in Bologna. With Jannik Sinner absent, Matteo Berrettini and Flavio Cobolli secured singles victories, giving Italy an unassailable 2-0 lead. This marks Italy’s fourth Davis Cup title overall and the first nation to win three in a row since the United States in the early 1970s.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness about Italy's victory in the Davis Cup but doesn't offer much depth or insight beyond the scoreline and the players involved. It doesn't provide any actionable insights, solutions, or deeper understanding of the sport.
